block.p: Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended April 7, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount, department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.
THE SAVAGE DETECTIVES, by Roberto BolaÃ$(1$)o. Translated by Natasha Wimmer. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.) A craftily autobiographical novel about a band of literary guerrillas.
SEIZURE, by Erica Wagner. (Norton, $23.95.) A troubled young Englishwoman inherits a seaside cottage and takes an unexpected lover.
ALL WHOM I HAVE LOVED, by Aharon Appelfeld. Translated by Aloma Halter. (Schocken, $23.) Family turmoil preoccupies a young Romanian Jewish boy on the eve of the Holocaust.
DELIRIUM, by Laura Restrepo. Translated by Natasha Wimmer. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $23.95.) In the '80s, a Colombian grapples with his wife's, and his country's, loss of memory.
THE MISTRESS'S DAUGHTER, by A. M. Homes. (Viking, $24.95.) Homes's dark memoir tells the story of her birth parents' re-entry into her life.
CULTURAL AMNESIA: Necessary Memories From History and the Arts, by Clive James. (Norton, $35.) Essays on 20th-century luminaries by one of Britain's funniest intellectuals.
KNOTS, by Nuruddin Farah. (Riverhead, $25.95.) After 20 years, a Somali woman returns to Mogadishu from Canada, intent on reclaiming a family house from a warlord.
SICK: The Untold Story of America's Health Care Crisis -- and the People Who Pay the Price, by Jonathan Cohn. (HarperCollins, $25.95.) The crisis through the experiences of ordinary people.

THE LONG EXILE: A Tale of Inuit Betrayal and Survival in the High Arctic, by Melanie McGrath. (Knopf, $24.95.) Canada's forced relocation of a group of Inuit in 1953 is now seen as one of the country's worst human rights violations.
PAPER TIGER, by Olivier Rolin. Translated by William Cloonan. (University of Nebraska; cloth, $40; paper, $17.95.) A French radical from the '60s explains ''the Cause'' to a dead friend's daughter.

THE STORY OF THE CANNIBAL WOMAN, by Maryse Condé. Translated by Richard Philcox. (Atria, $24.) A fictional portrait of a woman's grief after her longtime partner is murdered. The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books.
